channel.title: Computational Physics @ GT
channel.description: Computational Physics Group at Georgia Tech CSE

item.title: February 20, 2026
item.description: The group receives a DOE INCITE award of 750K node hours on OLCF Frontier for the project Exascale-enabled Simulation of Cavitation for Medicine and Beyond. PI Bryngelson, co-PIs T. Colonius, M. Rodriguez, F. Liu, and R. Budiardja.

item.title: February 19, 2026
item.description: Spencer is giving a talk at the RAeS Aerodynamics Workshop 2026 in London on characterizing soft materials at high strain rates using high-fidelity constitutive models and Bayesian comparison to experiments, as well as the use of surrogate models for turbulence and their utility from a computational budget perspective. Collaboration with UT Austin, Michigan, and Brown.

item.title: January 18, 2026
item.description: Our paper on MFC 5.0 (preprint here) was accepted for publication in Computer Physics Communications. Thanks to all the authors, collaborators, and referees!

item.title: January 8, 2026
item.description: Our AIAA SCITECH '26 conference paper, focusing on symbolic computational abstraction of chemistry libraries is now available online. Work with Ph.D. student Dimitrios Adam and UTSI faculty Esteban Cisneros-Garibay. We will be presenting it during the SCITECH forum next week, Jan 12-16, 2026.

item.title: December 22, 2025
item.description: A new group preprint appears on arXiv, led by graduate student Haocheng Yu and postdoc Tianyi Chu: Energy dissipation mechanisms in an acoustically-driven slit (Yu, Chu & Bryngelson, 2025), available on arXiv. Using direct numerical simulations and spectral proper orthogonal decomposition (SPOD), we quantify how incident acoustic energy is converted into vortical motion and viscous dissipation across sound pressure level, Strouhal number, and Reynolds number, identifying the coherent structures and mode-by-mode mechanisms that govern absorption. We show peak conversion near Keulegan-Carpenter number O(1) where boundary-layer separation and vortex shedding dominate damping, while higher frequencies reduce energy input via near-slit X-shaped modes and >99% of viscous loss remains confined near the slit mouth.

item.title: December 11, 2025
item.description: Our paper on Pyrometheus, which provides symbolic abstractions for XPU and automatic differention of thermochemistry/combustion was accepted and available at Computer Physics Communications. Collaboration with Prof. Esteban Cisneros-Garibay at UTSI, group Ph.D. student Dimitrios Adam, and group alumni Henry Le Berre.

item.title: December 4, 2025
item.description: Georgia Tech runs a story on our rocket simulations, as discussed heretofore. This is closely related to the ACM 2025 Gordon Bell Finalist work with former GT faculty, new at the Courant Institute, Prof. Florian Schaefer.

item.title: November 26, 2025
item.description: Our group collaborated with Diego Vaca-Revelo and Aswin Gnanaskandan of WPI on the hardware acceleration of bubbly flow models in Navier-Stokes solvers, demonstrated in MFC. The preprint is available here.

item.title: November 24, 2025
item.description: Our group, along with collaborators at UT-Austin, Michigan, and Brown, have pushed a preprint on Bayesian model selection for soft materials at very high strain rates. It's available here!

item.title: November 22, 2025
item.description: We are at APS DFD 2025 in Houston for the next few days. Ben, Spencer, and Tianyi are giving talks. Say hello if you see us!

item.title: November 19, 2025
item.description: Lawrence Livermore National Lab ran a nice story about our work on the largest and fastest CFD simulation (in particular on El Capitan), which is a 2025 ACM Gordon Bell Finalist. NVIDIA also posted about us in a blog post on their website.

item.title: November 15, 2025
item.description: Much of the group is at SC25 this week. Spencer is giving invited talks at the OpenACC BoF and the Gordon Bell Prize presentations on Tuesday and the NVIDIA Booth on Wednesday. Ben Wilfong is giving a paper talk at the HPCTESTS workshop.

item.title: October 25, 2025
item.description: Spencer published a paper in Computers and Fluids. It presents a scheme that can integrate for the moments of radial bubble dynamics with time-independent spectral accuracy.

item.title: October 21, 2025
item.description: Group Ph.D. student Haocheng Yu leads work that now appears on arXiv. Collaboration with Profs. L. Sankar and K. Ahuja in AE. The work focuses on high amplitude sound through good but still imperfect ear plugs, and the physical mechanisms that maintain them.

item.title: October 20, 2025
item.description: NCSA has written a piece on the group and our collaborator's work towards the Gordon Bell Prize and its use of the Grace Hopper architecture. Find it here.

item.title: October 16, 2025
item.description: Spencer presents our work, Symbolic Computational Representations of Combustion Thermochemistry, at the 2025 International Conference on Numerical Combustion in Rome, Italy. Part of a collaboration with Prof. Esteban Cisneros-Garibay at the University of Tennessee Space Institute; the work is also conducted by CSE Ph.D. student Dimitrios Adam and (nominally) Spencer. We achieve near-peak compute performance on diverse accelerators for diverse flavors of chemical reactions via optimal symbolic traversal of the computational graph.

item.title: October 7, 2025
item.description: Spencer is a select speaker at the OAC Summit today.

item.title: September 30, 2025
item.description: Oak Ridge National Laboratory publishes news on our Gordon Bell finalist effort simulating many-rocket exhaust at high Mach, exceeding 1 quadrillion degrees of freedom.

item.title: September 30, 2025
item.description: Postdoc Dr. Tianyi Chi and Ph.D. student Ben Wilfong lead published work that now appears in Phys. Rev. Fluids. They discover a new hydrodynamic instability at the confluence of Faraday and Rayleigh-Taylor modes, which we demonstrate in numerical experiments and linear Floquet theory. Shout out to collaborators Tim Koehler and Ryan McMullen at Sandia for the collaboration.

item.title: September 29, 2025
item.description: Collaborative work on representing transient and melting heat transfer on quantum devices appears on arXiv. Ph.D. student contributors include Chris Jawetz (ME) and Jack Song (Physics).
